Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I was sitting on the couch with Mia, my girlfriend, when her phone buzzed. She read the message, her face falling. “They said my project isn’t good enough,” she whispered, eyes brimming with tears. I reached for her hand, wanting to be the anchor she needed, to listen and reassure her that she was more than her boss’s opinion. But before I could say anything, the building’s alarm blared, and a robotic voice announced a flash-flood warning. I glanced out the window—water was already pooling in the street, creeping up the sidewalk. My phone buzzed with an emergency alert: residents were urged to help neighbors evacuate and check on the elderly. I felt torn in two. Mia’s shoulders shook beside me, needing comfort and my full attention. But as a citizen, I knew I should be out there, helping others, doing my part for the community. My heart pounded as I looked from Mia’s tear-streaked face to the rising water outside, caught between the person she needed and the citizen my city expected me to be.
